element.short: Encapsulation of resources for a specific project or organization.
element.definition: Encapsulation of resources for a specific project or organization.
The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
The base language in which the resource is written.
A name associated with the Project.
A summary, characterization or explanation of the Project.

element.short: Whether this project is the super administrator project.
element.definition: Whether this project is the super administrator project. A super administrator is a user who has complete access to all resources in all projects.

element.short: Whether this project uses strict FHIR validation.
element.definition: Whether this project uses strict FHIR validation.

element.short: Whether this project uses referential integrity on write operations such as 'create' and 'update'.
element.definition: Whether this project uses referential integrity on write operations such as 'create' and 'update'.
The user who owns the project.
A list of optional features that are enabled for the project.
The default access policy for patients using open registration.
Secure environment variable that can be used to store secrets for bots.
The secret name.
The secret value.
Web application or web site that is associated with the project.
Friendly name that will make it easy for you to identify the site in the future.

The list of domain names associated with the site. User authentication will be restricted to the domains you enter here, plus any subdomains. In other words, a registration for example.com also registers subdomain.example.com. A valid domain requires a host and must not include any path, port, query or fragment.
The publicly visible Google Client ID for the site. This is used to authenticate users with Google. This value is available in the Google Developer Console.
The private Google Client Secret for the site. This value is available in the Google Developer Console.
The publicly visible reCAPTCHA site key. This value is generated when you create a new reCAPTCHA site in the reCAPTCHA admin console. Use this site key in the HTML code your site serves to users.
The private reCAPTCHA secret key. This value is generated when you create a new reCAPTCHA site in the reCAPTCHA admin console. Use this secret key for communication between your site and reCAPTCHA.

element.short: Medplum client application for automated access.
element.definition: Medplum client application for automated access.
The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
The base language in which the resource is written.
A name associated with the ClientApplication.
A summary, characterization or explanation of the ClientApplication.
Client secret string used to verify the identity of a client.
Optional JWKS URI for public key verification of JWTs issued by the authorization server (client_secret_jwt).
Optional redirect URI used when redirecting a client back to the client application.
Optional launch URI for SMART EHR launch sequence.
Flag to make PKCE optional for this client application. PKCE is required by default for compliance with Smart App Launch. It can be disabled for compatibility with legacy client applications.
Optional external Identity Provider (IdP) for the client application.

resource.name: User
resource.description: Representation of a human user of the system.

element.short: Representation of a human user of the system
element.definition: Representation of a human user of the system.
The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
The base language in which the resource is written.
The first name or given name of the user. This is the value as entered when the user is created. It is used to populate the profile resource.
The last name or family name of the user. This is the value as entered when the user is created. It is used to populate the profile resource.
DEPRECATED Replaced by ProjectMembership.externalId.
The email address that uniquely identifies the user.
Whether the system has verified that the user has access to the email address.
DEPRECATED
Encrypted hash of the user's password.
Shared secret for MFA authenticator applications.
Whether the user has completed MFA enrollment.
Optional project if the user only exists for the project. This is used for the project-specific user database.

resource.name: ProjectMembership
resource.description: Medplum project membership. A project membership grants a user access to a project.

element.short: Medplum project membership. A project membership grants a user access to a project.
element.definition: Medplum project membership. A project membership grants a user access to a project.
The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
The base language in which the resource is written.
Project where the memberships are available.
The project administrator who invited the user to the project.
User that is granted access to the project.
Reference to the resource that represents the user profile within the project.

A String that is an identifier for the resource as defined by the provisioning client.  The "externalId" may simplify identification of a resource between the provisioning client and the service provider by allowing the client to use a filter to locate the resource with an identifier from the provisioning domain, obviating the need to store a local mapping between the provisioning domain's identifier of the resource and the identifier used by the service provider.  Each resource MAY include a non-empty "externalId" value.  The value of the "externalId" attribute is always issued by the provisioning client and MUST NOT be specified by the service provider.  The service provider MUST always interpret the externalId as scoped to the provisioning domain.
The access policy for the user within the project memebership.
Extended access configuration using parameterized access policies.
The base access policy used as a template.  Variables in the template access policy are replaced by the values in the parameter.
User options that control the display of the application.
The unique name of the parameter.
Value of the parameter - must be one of a constrained set of the data types (see [Extensibility](extensibility.html) for a list).
The user configuration for the user within the project memebership such as menu links, saved searches, and features.

element.short: Whether this user is a project administrator.
element.definition: Whether this user is a project administrator.
Bot account for automated actions.
The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
The base language in which the resource is written.
An identifier for this bot.
A name associated with the Bot.
A summary, characterization or explanation of the Bot.
The identifier of the bot runtime environment (i.e., vmcontext, awslambda, etc).
Image of the bot.
A schedule for the bot to be executed.
Bot logic script.
A code that classifies the service for searching, sorting and display purposes (e.g. "Surgical Procedure").
element.comment: There may be multiple axis of categorization depending on the context or use case for retrieving or displaying the resource.  The level of granularity is defined by the category concepts in the value set.

element.definition: Optional flag to indicate that the bot should be run as the user.
Login event and session details.
The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
The base language in which the resource is written.
The client requesting the code.
Optional required profile resource type.
Optional required project for the login.
The user requesting the code.
Reference to the project membership which includes FHIR identity (patient, practitioner, etc), access policy, and user configuration.
OAuth scope or scopes.
The authentication method used to obtain the code (password or google).
Time when the End-User authentication occurred.
The cookie value that can be used for session management.

The authorization code generated by the authorization server.  The authorization code MUST expire shortly after it is issued to mitigate the risk of leaks.  A maximum authorization code lifetime of 10 minutes is RECOMMENDED.  The client MUST NOT use the authorization code more than once.  If an authorization code is used more than once, the authorization server MUST deny the request and SHOULD revoke (when possible) all tokens previously issued based on that authorization code.  The authorization code is bound to the client identifier and redirection URI.
PKCE code challenge presented in the authorization request.
OPTIONAL, defaults to "plain" if not present in the request.  Code verifier transformation method is "S256" or "plain".
Optional secure random string that can be used in an OAuth refresh token.
Optional cryptographically random string that your app adds to the initial request and the authorization server includes inside the ID Token, used to prevent token replay attacks.
Whether the user has verified using multi-factor authentication (MFA). This will only be set is the user has MFA enabled (see User.mfaEnrolled).
Whether a token has been granted for this login.
Whether this login has been revoked or invalidated.
DEPRECATED
Whether this login has super administrator privileges.
Optional SMART App Launch context for this login.
The Internet Protocol (IP) address of the client or last proxy that sent the request.
The User-Agent request header as sent by the client.

Whether this request has been used, and is therefore no longer valid.

resource.name: JsonWebKey
resource.description: A JSON object that represents a cryptographic key. The members of the object represent properties of the key, including its value.

element.short: A JSON object that represents a cryptographic key.
element.definition: A JSON object that represents a cryptographic key. The members of the object represent properties of the key, including its value.
The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
The base language in which the resource is written.
Whether this key is in active use.
The specific cryptographic algorithm used with the key.
The family of cryptographic algorithms used with the key.
How the key was meant to be used; sig represents the signature.
The operation(s) for which the key is intended to be used.
The x.509 certificate chain. The first entry in the array is the certificate to use for token verification; the other certificates can be used to verify this first certificate.
The modulus for the RSA public key.
The exponent for the RSA public key.
The unique identifier for the key.
The thumbprint of the x.509 cert (SHA-1 thumbprint).
The exponent for the RSA private key.
The first prime factor.
The second prime factor.
The first factor CRT exponent.
The second factor CRT exponent.
The first CRT coefficient.

resource.name: AccessPolicy
resource.description: Access Policy for user or user group that defines how entities can or cannot access resources.

element.short: Access Policy for user or user group that defines how entities can or cannot access resources.
element.definition: Access Policy for user or user group that defines how entities can or cannot access resources.

The base language in which the resource is written.
A name associated with the AccessPolicy.
Optional compartment for newly created resources.  If this field is set, any resources created by a user with this access policy will automatically be included in the specified compartment.
Access details for a resource type.
The resource type.
DEPRECATED Optional compartment restriction for the resource type.
The rules that the server should use to determine which resources to allow.
element.comment: The rules are search criteria (without the [base] part). Like Bundle.entry.request.url, it has no leading "/".

element.definition: Optional flag to indicate that the resource type is read-only.
Optional list of hidden fields.  Hidden fields are not readable or writeable.
Optional list of read-only fields.  Read-only fields are readable but not writeable.
Use IP Access Rules to allowlist, block, and challenge traffic based on the visitor IP address.
Friendly name that will make it easy for you to identify the IP Access Rule in the future.
An IP Access rule will apply a certain action to incoming traffic based on the visitor IP address or IP range.
Access rule can perform one of the following actions: "allow" | "block".

Shortcut links to URLs.
The human friendly name of the link.

resource.name: BulkDataExport
resource.description: User specific configuration for the Medplum application.

element.short: User specific configuration for the Medplum application.
element.definition: User specific configuration for the Medplum application.
The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.

The base language in which the resource is written.
The status of the request.
Indicates the server's time when the query is requested.

Indicates the server's time when the query is run. The response SHOULD NOT include any resources modified after this instant, and SHALL include any matching resources modified up to and including this instant.
The full URL of the original Bulk Data kick-off request. In the case of a POST request, this URL will not include the request parameters.
Indicates whether downloading the generated files requires the same authorization mechanism as the $export operation itself.
An array of file items with one entry for each generated file. If no resources are returned from the kick-off request, the server SHOULD return an empty array.
The FHIR resource type that is contained in the file.

binding.description: One of the resource types defined as part of this version of FHIR.

element.definition: The absolute path to the file. The format of the file SHOULD reflect that requested in the _outputFormat parameter of the initial kick-off request.
An array of deleted file items following the same structure as the output array.
The FHIR resource type that is contained in the file.

binding.description: One of the resource types defined as part of this version of FHIR.

element.definition: The absolute path to the file. The format of the file SHOULD reflect that requested in the _outputFormat parameter of the initial kick-off request.
Array of message file items following the same structure as the output array.
The FHIR resource type that is contained in the file.

binding.description: One of the resource types defined as part of this version of FHIR.

element.definition: The absolute path to the file. The format of the file SHOULD reflect that requested in the _outputFormat parameter of the initial kick-off request.
